The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: A VINDICATION OF Lieut. Col. JOHN LILBURNE, and others.
div.p:
DAvid Browne the Pamphleteer, who undertaketh to teach men to write in ≈øix hours, is one whom LIEUT. COL. JOHN LILBORN, and my ≈øelfe, with divers others whom hee maliciou≈øly inveighs again≈øt, have releived, or el≈øe he and his Family might have peri≈øhed (for ought I know,) And ≈øince he was delivered unto Satan, for his wicked and notorious lies, and di≈ø≈øimulations, the devill in who≈øe hands he is, hath ≈øtirred him up to be more envious and malicious then ever, that he may be transformed more perfectly in to his own image, Who walketh to and fro like a roaring Lyon ≈øeeking whom he may devoure, and per≈øecuting the Church who is cloathed with the Sun of Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and unto who≈øe feet the Law of God is a light, making warre with the remnant of her ≈øeed who keep the te≈øtimony of God, and the faith of Je≈øus. And his malice is principally bent again≈øt tho≈øe who are mo≈øt con≈øcientious and precious in the eyes of the Lord, as may appear in the ≈øtory
of holy Job, who was greatly afflicted on every ≈øide, both in his Per≈øon, Name and E≈øtate, but in due time God vindicated his reputation before all men, and did ble≈ø≈øe his latter end more then his beginning, and ≈øo if we mark the end of ≈øuch perfect and upright per≈øons, behold it is peace, but the wicked is like the raging Sea foaming out mire and dirt, meer mire and dirt; ≈øomewhat like to the dirty Pamphlet of David Brown the Scotti≈øhman, the Fronti≈ø-peece whereof, ≈øeemeth to in≈øinuate to the ≈øimple hone≈øt Reader, as if LIEUT. COL. JOHN LILBORNE, my ≈øelfe, and Mr. Mu≈øgrave were prodigious Con≈øpirators, and bloody Petitioners, but he that reads the Pamphlet may perceive that he hath no ≈øuch thing again≈øt us, ble≈ø≈øed be God: But the ≈øum of it is, A remembrance to put the Parliament in mind of the di≈øcovery which he made of a Malignant Petition, wherein he complaineth that he was not rewarded for the ≈øaid Di≈øcovery, and ≈øtileth him≈øelfe and his Family, the Parliaments Remembrancers, ≈øo his whole Petitionary Remon≈øtrance is a begging bu≈øine≈ø≈øe for maintenance, and protection from Arre≈øts.

Surely he thought that now, now was the time for him to ≈øtrike while the iron was hot, and that now the Parliament were nece≈ø≈øitated to hear and receive his coun≈øel and to regard him, and reward him, ≈øeeing he had taken upon him now, in the heat of all the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to be their Advocate, and to plead their cau≈øe again≈øt poor Lilborne who was down, and therefore according to the Proverb, downe with him, but its well that neither the Parliament nor Sir Arthur He≈øilrige ≈øtand in need of the untempered morter, of ≈øuch unskilfull Daubers, to maintain their Bulwarks again≈øt the Levellers, I hope rather then they will countenance ≈øuch revengefull ≈øpirits, they
will feed their Enemy when he is hungry, and give him drink when he is thir≈øty; for the Parliament of them≈øelves are very milde to their Enemies, if not provoked again≈øt them by ≈øome others.

It may be that this Pamphleteir thought that rather then he would want worke, he would ≈øet him≈øelfe on work, if the Devill will find him tooles: but as Chri≈øt would not have ≈øuch Advocates to confe≈ø≈øe that he was the Son of God, but commanded the Devills to hold their peace; So its better for the Parliament to ≈øilence ≈øuch Babblers, then to ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be ≈øo di≈øgraced, by having their prai≈øe ≈øet forth in ≈øcurrillous Pamplets, ≈øuch as this Authours, who not knowing which way to be revenged of me, for doing my duty in the Church of which I am (and he was) a Member, he laboreth to make me as odious as he can to the world, and to the State, and at the time of Lilbornes ≈øad ≈øentence, chargeth me in chiefe, with him and divers others in general in his Pamphlet to the Parliament, with fal≈øene≈ø≈øe, manifold calumniations, corrupt practi≈øes, unju≈øt dealings, deceit, fraud, ambition, covetou≈ønes, and ≈øelfe-≈øeeking, and unju≈øt Levelling; and though he chargeth divers others with me, yet he hath not named them, no more doth he come to particulars to ≈øhew wherein we are as he chargeth us. And truly though I hope well for my Neighbours, yet I beleeve for my ≈øelfe: And if I thought it expedient to Vindicate my ≈øelfe from the title of Leveller, I would tell this fal≈øe Accu≈øer, that if I am a Leveller, I am no Leveller of the Vallies, but a Leveller of the MOUNTAINS, that the way of Je≈øus Chri≈øt may be prepared, that all fle≈øh may ≈øee the ≈øalvation of our God, and this was the de≈øigne of John the Bapti≈øt, and I hope no hone≈øt man will be offended with me for this manner of
Levelling, nor account it unju≈øt, But Herod heard John the Bapti≈øt gladly, but at la≈øt he cut off his head, and ≈øo he levelled the hone≈øt Leveller. Moreover I am ≈øo far from levelling the Lawes, That if the Parliament would put in practice their Legi≈ølative power, and ca≈øt a≈øide all the Lawes of the Land, the Lawes excepted which they have no power to aboli≈øh, and yeeld obedience to tho≈øe good Laws and none but ≈øuch, they may ≈øit long enough for me, I would not be forward to ≈øeek a new Repre≈øentative, but a true Repre≈øentative; But oh! Where ≈øhall we find men of courage, fearing God and hating covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe? therefore my opinion is, its better to have and to hold the≈øe that we have, then have wor≈øe, the Proverb is, Seldome comes a better, But when the Land doth mend, I would have this Parliament end, and not till then. So far am I from unju≈øt Levelling, that I would not pull an old hou≈øe over mine head, but prepare ≈øufficient materialls to build up another, that ≈øhould be rather better then wor≈øe then the former, and to have a care what I doe, for Salomon ≈øaith, He that rolleth a ≈øtone it ≈øhal fal upon him, and he that breaketh a hedge, a Serpent ≈øhall bite him. Concerning LIEU.COL. JOHN LILBURNE, I have known the man a long time, even from the time of his ≈øufferings by the blody Bi≈øhops, and as hee was an in≈øtrumental means to pul them from their ≈øeats, ≈øo was he the main In≈øtrument to rent in peeces Regall Tyranny, and the whole Hou≈øe of Lords, which works were long attempted, and many on≈øets and repul≈øes before the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe could be brought to that de≈øirable perfection which was long ≈øought for, with labour and watching, and wearine≈ø≈øe, and hazzard of life, and expence of blood and trea≈øure, and at length the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe was accompli≈øhed by the Army and Parliament.

And now I mu≈øt ≈øay this on the behalfe of Lieu. Col. Chidley's charity to Lilburn. Lilburn, that what≈øoever the matter is now, unle≈ø≈øe he bee much altered from what he was, his nature is ≈øo good that hee is not a man given to complaine, but where the ≈øhooe wringeth him; if men will let him alone, he will let them alone, and in his dealings in the world he hath been very punctuall, neither can I tax him with any corrupt practi≈øes, or unju≈øt dealings, I have found him a plain, blunt, down right hone≈øt man; he wil play above board, and he that playeth with him ≈øhall have faire quarter: He is not of ≈øuch a revengefull ≈øpirit to take his Adver≈øarie at advantages, and when he is down and at the weake≈øt to tread upon him: And concerning ambition, doubtle≈ø≈øe, he hath ≈øeemed to me as if he were prodigall of his owne life, and blood, and ≈øtrength, and liberty, and all that was dear to him for the good of this Commonwealth: He was an in≈øtrument under God, that kept the Parliament from immediate de≈øtruction, for he defended them with his ≈øword from Lunsfords Crew, Lilburnes ambition. ≈øo it ≈øeems to me all along as if he had been ambitious for Knocks, for a Pri≈øon, a Dungeon, a Pillory, a Whip, a Gagge, yea, and death it ≈øelfe, and yet he is alive at this day, though he hath ≈øought to loo≈øe it, yet hath he found it: And touching covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, I hope he is free, I have known him to be liberall, and to be willing to ≈øpend and be ≈øpent for others when he hath wanted it him≈øelf, and I am ≈øure he is no Churle, but ready to do good to his ability; And had he been as Mr. Brown chargeth him, a Selfe-Seeker, crafty and deceitful, he might have feathered his ne≈øt ten times better then he hath done, but he was like a candle lighted, accommodating others, and con≈øuming him≈øelf: Yea, hee who declareth him≈øelfe in Print again≈øt Lilburn, hath
received of him divers great ≈øums of money, but Lilburn complained that he could not get Brown to come to an account with him, though he often de≈øired it, ≈øo fal≈øe was he to him, as he was to the poore of our Church, and I know not that he hath preferred any of us to any e≈øtate, much le≈ø≈øe a great e≈øtate, as he braggeth.

Indeed once I imployed him to copy out a Letter, becau≈øe it ≈øhould be in his hand-writing, and not in mine, and an ordinary Scrivener would have done it for ≈øix pence, but I thought it was better to imploy a brother in fellow≈øhip, then a ≈øtranger to write for me, and the truth is, I have done him no wrong, unle≈ø≈øe it were dropping in his hands peeces of gold & ≈øilver, which wrong he could, and did pocket up, and I could never get it to this day; no more could my mother get hers, which he came in a deceitfull way, and borrowed, and never paid, and it may be ≈øhee is the woman he ≈øpeakes of in his Pamphlet, though he chargeth her with nothing; and if ≈øo, I mu≈øt ≈øay that ≈øhe hath done more good for the Commonwealth in one quarter of a yeare, then he hath done, or, it may be, will doe all his life time, for God hath made her an in≈øtrument to de≈øtroy the Forelorne hope, and totally to rout all the forces of Mr. Edwards, that great Champion for the Church of England, as may appeare by her workes extant in Print.

And concerning Mr. MUSGRAVE, he is knowne to be a very hone≈øt Gentleman, and one that was an Agent for his County, and performed his tru≈øt with diligence, and faithfulne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øtood to his tacklings to the la≈øt, and though he were impri≈øoned wrongfully, in due time God relea≈øed him by meanes of the Army, when they came to London. The man is a man of good parts, having been bred up in the Law from his youth,
and al≈øo he is ver≈øed in the Scripture, which is be≈øt of all; and had he but the abilities of Lilburne in expre≈ø≈øing him≈øelfe, and that ≈øtrength of memory withall, hee would confound the Lawyers. But indeed, I have thought him ≈øomewhat too har≈øh to the Parliament men, and thought that if he dealt more mildly with them, and with more humility, his words would bee more acceptable unto them; but I have knowne it a frequent thing with him when I have walked with him in the ≈øtreets, he would make no more to reprove a Parliament man, or an Officer of the Army, then I would of reproving my ≈øervant.

As concerning the re≈øt of the per≈øons whom Mr. Brown inveighes again≈øt, though he name no man, yet I partly gue≈ø≈øe whom he meanes, and what it is that di≈øta≈øtes him, becau≈øe that they would not give him money for printing the whim≈øes of his owne braine, and ≈øuch crotchets as they were a≈øhamed of. Indeed if he had kept to their rules, and directions, and printed nothing, nor no more of a ≈øort then they gave him order to print, nor foy≈øted in his own tedious ≈øtuffe to the di≈øparagement of that party of which he was a wi≈øe one, in his owne conceit, then he might have expected wages for his work. But when LIEU. COL. LILBURNE had writen a matter, and delivered it to him to print, and money to di≈øcharge the Printers; he would be ≈øtealing and foy≈øting in ≈øome mad ≈øtuffe or other, of his own, that would make hone≈øt Lilburne very much vexe and chafe, and then he would put it out againe, and ≈øend him againe to undoe what he had in≈øerted.

And as touching the private contributions, the Accu≈øer ≈øpeakes of charging me to be their Trea≈øurer, I neither did unju≈øtly di≈øpo≈øe thereof, nor inrich my ≈øelfe thereby, but am out of pur≈øe, and had I the money in
my hand againe, I would not pay it out contrary to the order of tho≈øe who intru≈øted me, who were morall hone≈øt men, and ≈øo long as they did the things that were right, I joyned with them, and wherein I thought they were wrong, I would not ≈øigne to any of their Petitions, till I were ≈øatisfied, much le≈ø≈øe print any idle projects, as this Pamphleteer alleadgeth; and ≈øo when they made inqui≈øition for the blood of one that was ≈øhot to death at Ware, I would not ≈øub≈øcribe it; becau≈øe I di≈øowned the Title; but I told the Hou≈øe when I was examined at the Bar, that although I ≈øub≈øcribed not the Petition, yet I owned the Petition, ≈øo farre as FROM THE LATTER END OF THE TITLE, TO THE END OF THE PETITION. The Title was THE SUPREAME AUTHORITY, and at that time, THE PARLIAMENT owned THE KING, and HOUSE OF LORDS, and were di≈øta≈øted at ≈øuch as ≈øtiled them, The Supream Authority, as ≈øavouring of levelling, yet notwith≈øtanding I was committed to the Gate-hou≈øe, but afterwards when the Army had conquered the King and his party, purged the Hou≈øe, and owned THE PARLIAMENT for the SUPREAM AUTHORITY, and that the Hou≈øe of Commons threw downe the Hou≈øe of Lords, then I knew that they were the Supream Authority, and have owned them ever ≈øince, and have done them faithfull ≈øervice, and offices of love in endeavouring to make reconciliation betwixt party and party; and to per≈øwade them that they may ≈øit downe quietly under this pre≈øent Government, and it is well knowne what paines and labour I be≈øtowed to make a hand≈øome compo≈øure, and I did not altogether faile of my de≈øires and expectation. But in this bu≈øines of Sir. Arthur He≈øleriges I medled not having had matters of more
publike concernment to be exerci≈øed in, and thinking that Lilburne had ≈øuch to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him who were more skilfull in the Law of England then my ≈øelfe.

Whereas the accu≈øer ≈øaith, that Printing hath beene our chiefe≈øt weapon, and by that occa≈øion, that wee have great corre≈øpondency with Printers, and ≈øome of us ready to print what we plea≈øe again≈øt them.

I an≈øwer, that my judgement is not for printing of here≈øie or bla≈øphemy, or matter of ≈øcandall, or a lye, but onely the truth, and I hold it one of the greate≈øt abu≈øes of the Commonwealth, that ≈øo many lying fooli≈øh Pamphlets have been, and are ≈øuffered to go abroad; ≈øurely the Printers have much to an≈øwer for at the day of judgement, ≈øeeing for every idle word which a man ≈øhall ≈øpeak, he mu≈øt an≈øwer for at the day of Judgement, ≈øo farre am I from holding a corre≈øpondence with them, that I pronounce the judgements of God again≈øt them, ≈øaying, Woe unto you Printers, for you have much to an≈øwer for: I have been more carefull what I print, then what I write or ≈øpeak, becau≈øe if a man print an Impre≈ø≈øion of fifteen hundred books, peradventure they may be ≈øpread to 15000. per≈øons, and leven them all, and its (in a maner) impo≈ø≈øible to recal them; Now who≈øoever readeth the la≈øt lea≈øe of this our Accu≈øers Pamphlet, will have occa≈øion to think the man not to bee of very deep judgement, for though the Pre≈ø≈øe is free for all men both knaves and fooles, as well as wi≈øe men, provided they put their names to it, and the Printer his name, which is too large a latitude (as I humbly conceive) Yet our Accu≈øer would have the Parliaments order to print again≈øt us, and layeth downe a po≈øitive Law, as if he and his family were a high Commi≈ø≈øion; or Spani≈øh Inqui≈øition, yea and wor≈øe; viz. that what≈øoever
Queries they ≈øhall propound to us, if we an≈øwer them not within the ≈øpace of three months and a day, ≈øhall be held thenceforth as confe≈ø≈øed; But if the Parliament ≈øhould condi≈øcend to his ba≈øe propo≈øition, wee would not en≈ølave our ≈øelves to ≈øuch a tyrannicall Law, for we have learned of a wi≈øer, not to an≈øwer a foole according to his folly; neverthele≈ø≈øe our Accu≈øer before he knew whether we would in≈ølave our ≈øelves to his ba≈øe propo≈øition, he promi≈øed with his family the like ba≈øe conditions again≈øt them≈øelves, ≈øo they have made them≈øelves ≈ølaves by promi≈øe, but he craveth the equall benefit of the Pre≈ø≈øe, competent meanes of ≈øub≈øi≈øtance, and monies to Printers, but I hope the Parliament will not put, but rather wre≈øt the ≈øword out of ≈øuch mad mens hands, and will not afford the like benefit to ≈ølaves by promi≈øe, as to tho≈øe who have not made any ≈øuch obligation, nor ca≈øt away the Commonwealths money to them, or their Printers, unle≈ø≈øe it were for a better purpo≈øe then to propagate that hatefull ≈øinne of ≈øowing ≈øtrife among≈øt brethren.

But above all per≈øons, this Accu≈øer hath a great fling at me, and yet his ≈øling-≈øtones are but as ≈øtubble, but his madne≈ø≈øe is becau≈øe he was ca≈øt out of the Church, as may appear by his Pamphlet; herein he acteth the Dragons part, who was exceeding wrath after hee ≈øaw he was ca≈øt out of Heaven, and therefore though the Heavens are called to rejoyce, yet a woe is pronounced to the Earth and the Inhabitants thereof, For the devill is come downe unto you, having great wrath, becau≈øe he knoweth he hath but a ≈øhort time.

Whereas he ≈øaith I was mo≈øt ju≈øtly by the direction of the Tru≈øtees, expul≈øed both from my Office and lodgings at Worce≈øter hou≈øe, for deceitfull dealing and unju≈øt
Levelling in Civill matters there, again≈øt many both poore and rich; I deny that there was, or is any ≈øuch thing again≈øt me, ≈øurely, if there had been any ≈øuch thing the Tru≈øtees would have told me ≈øo; I deny not, but through their unadvi≈øednes there was very many complaints, which is a u≈øuall thing with the poorer ≈øort, to murmur again≈øt tho≈øe who have dealings with them, For their debts, not being paid by the Tru≈øtees according to their Bonds, cau≈øed poverty, and their poverty murmuring, But the Lord ≈øtilleth the raging Seas, and troublous murmurings of the people. Who can ≈øay ≈øince I came into Worce≈øter hou≈øe, that I have done the thing that is unju≈øt, and prove it? if the Tru≈øtees had been as forward to have protected me, as I them, from the Clamours of the rude People, things would have been carried well: And I know not that the Tru≈øtees have given any ≈øuch directions, as he ≈øaith, to expul≈øe me from my Office and Lodgings. Indeed I did depart from my Lodgings for another cau≈øe, and touching my Office, I was Receiver of all the Debenters, and the time was expired which is limited by the la≈øt Act. And ever ≈øince I have faithfully followed the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of the Commonwealth, for which I de≈øerve my Salary ≈øtill; and if the Tru≈øtees pay it not, I have ≈øo much confidence in their Superiours, that I ≈øhall have every penny. I have been a faithfull ≈øervant to the Commonwealth from the beginning, and have performed my place without extorting of Bribes, according to the univer≈øall di≈øea≈øe that is inbred among≈øt almo≈øt all Clerks, that make not the Word of God their rule.
